comments.commentBody: Shootings and other crimes go up each year seasonally and then decline as the calendar moves.   Is this quarterly fluctuation (in the midst of record summer heat) different from other quarterly fluctuations? It's reckless and both logically and scientifically meaningless to make claims about a crime trend based on one calendar quarter when these quarterly or monthly fluctuations have been going on for years.  Besides, do we know what else was going on in the City during the last calendar quarter when stops went down?  Did other aspects of police enforcement change? Were there fewer officers on the street, or were the same number there making fewer stops?  Were stops occurring at the rate same but recorded less often? Were arrests down as well as stops? Where did these declines take place, in Times Square or in higher crime places?  Shooting from the hip factually is not a sound or smart way to evaluate policies aimed at health and safety.

John in Arizona..

First, what city? New York City... since this is where I live and this is the topic of the editorial.

Second, I can not give you one specific citation for my claim, it is based on what I am reading in the news and seeing on television news.
Oh please,  600,000 stops and all of a sudden they are afraid? surely you jest.

Despite numbers in this editorial, is there a correlation between the decline in stop and frisk by police and the rise in shootings in the city that we've seen recently?

I would think it is more than mere coincidence. I think that some people aren't as afraid to carry an illegal gun around the city any more.
Somebody needs to inform these profound economic geniuses that pushing on ropes transmits no force.

"Policy makers get a little frustrated that they are not getting all the bang for their buck that they could".

The government is "investing" by the wrong means to boost this fenced sector of the economy. only resulting in richer private companies with no quantitative effect on the larger economy. Should have nationalized the banks when they were about to fail. Now we're hostages to these same crooks!

Richard - Can you please specify what "excessive threats to individual liberty or the rights of property" you are alluding to?  Also, I'm curious as to WHO specifically "believe(s) that any price is worth paying so long as their notion of the 'common good' is secured"  These are grand rhetorical flourishes, but what in heaven's name do they mean?
Whining progressive, why should I be forced into SS when so many gov employees are not ?
That has always been the underlying plan.

The reaction of the Democratic Party to Mark Clayton winning the Senate primary in Tennessee versus that of the GOP to Ted Cruz, Todd Akin, and Richard Mourdock winning the Senate primaries in Texas, Missouri, and Indiana, respectively, says a lot about the two political parties and how only one of the parties remains sane.

In Tennessee, the Democratic Party is actively disavowing Clayton and urging Democrats to write in another candidate in November. By contrast, the GOP has happily embraced Cruz, Akin, and Mourdock despite or, more likely, because of their extremist beliefs.

Perhaps the most disturbing of the extremist beliefs shared by Cruz, Akin, and Mourdock is that Medicare and Social Security are somehow unconstitutional. Such a retrograde view of the Constitution has been rightly rejected by the U.S. Supreme Court since the mid-1930s and would return us to the days when the federal government was virtually powerless to take any actions to promote the common good or to address major issues facing our nation and people. And it would be a massive blow to the middle class in the US, which Social Security and Medicare have helped to create.

Republican Senate candidates like Cruz, Akin, and Mourdock demonstrate yet further evidence that the GOP is gunning for our Medicare and Social Security. It is up to us to stop them this November.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236

The problem is "the goal".
This goal is not to create an economic model that works for everyone, one that promotes the exchange of a common currency for goods and services, and therefore a healthy well functioning society. Rather, it is to make the economy a ludicrous game that allows for corruption and swindling of all sorts, rewarding the worst possible elements of the human condition.
Will we ever rise above this?

comments.commentTitle: Twin Prostitutes, Growing Old Plying Their Trade in Amsterdam
comments.commentBody: Amsterdam, known for "De Walletjes," and New Amsterdam (New York now), known for "Wallstreet," share the following negatives: Both are based on make believe and both are expensive.

If the pilot is using the iPad and notices it having an effect on the operation of the plane, they can immediately turn off the iPad and eliminate the problem.  If a passenger is using one, the pilot has no idea of that fact and can not quickly and easily eliminate the interference.  Even if they make an announcement to the passengers to turn off all equipment, that takes time and many passengers will not obey anyway.
The 'special, magical property' iPads have is 'airplane mode' (along with the iPhone).  Manuals can be accessed without the need for wi-fi or a cellular data network.

francine

It is a fact, reported in a military news outlet, that the Marine Corp is eliminating 20,000 marines (meaning they have no option to re-elist). This number includes veterans that served in Iraq and Afghanistan. This number also includes commissioned officers and non-commission officers. This number includes the very heart and soul of the marines (those that had career motives) and those that actually are the motivators for the new recruits.

They want to stay in service of our country, and they are being rejected by the Obama policies, while the spending in Washington goes on unabated.

President Obama has his priorities misplaced. He will stand by the umions of policeman, fireman, teachers, and the list goes on (unions). But for some reason, only known by him, he has targeted the elite fighting force in our country, the Marine Corp. The very people that have met our enemy in foreign lands to protect us, too many never to return alive, and too many with lost limbs and traces of battle scars.

It is no wonder why Obama lacks far behind Romney in voter support among the military. He is taking the living spirit (the motivation that inspired them initially to enlist) from them, and trashed it like some item on a financial spreadsheet.

There will be more to come before the election, about the Obama priorties targeting the military.

Our veterans (those that want to stay in the military) are being rejected by President Obama...it is a fact...knowing one first hand.
I have had a similar situation with United.  Unfortunately, for my job, that is the airline contracted with--and I just hate them.  They are so bad.  And continental was so good!

Seriously? There's one good reason for banning electronic devices during take-off and landing: it discourages passengers from being [totally] oblivious to their surroundings during the two most dangerous sections of the flight. Especially at take-off, there's no good reason to be lost in a digital haze.
Are people so devoid of intelligence and imagination that they can't go 15 minutes without their gadgets?

"Better safe than sorry" is a mindless explanation from the FAA regarding their ban on electronic devices with no evidence. This administration promised us science-based policies, and instead has continued the superstition-based policy of the past.

We all know that a very thorough unplanned experiment has already been done: People leave their devices turned on, buried in purses and pockets, all the time, whether purposely or accidentally. No planes have fallen from the sky.

I couldn't even read this NYT story on my Kindle during takeoff under current rules, but I could read it on the print edition. But what if that newspaper burst into flames from the rays of the sun coming through the window? There's no reason to believe it could, but....better safe than sorry.

The reporter should challenge this nonsense rather than accept the FAA's sanctimonious response to her inquiry.

Glass filters UVB rays, but not UVA. Windshields are treated to filter UVA, but most car windows are not. I definitely get sunburns on my left arm after a long drive, and my mother has significant sun damage on her left arm and hand, but not on her right.

Sunscreen in your car? What! There's no UV penetration of any windows I'm aware of. I wear transition lenses and they don't darken regardless of the glare in the car - unless I let the top down. Please read what you write.

San Diego.

On a flight a few months ago, some previous traveler had stuffed a blood-stained kleenex into the seat pocket. At least I saw it before reaching into the pocket.

Planes are really, really gross now, and cleaning seems to be minimal. Since I live on the opposite side of the continent from my family, I have no choice but to fly. But I try to touch as little as possible and use hand sanitizer repeatedly during every flight.
Poor thing. I love to fly. The food's not so terrible, and on long flights I'm sound asleep. In economy.

An otherwise completely healthy friend of mine recently died from a deep vein thrombosis after a long-haul flight of more than half a day across Europe and Asia. The way they pack folks in the cheap seats is a crime. Whatever you do, besides not touching the sink in the bathroom, is don't just sit there. However awkward it is and however many funny looks you get, walk the aisles at least one an hour on those long flights, also known as cruel and unusual punishment.

My approach to flying these days is to Thank God for Small Mercies. Like the current ban on cell phone yacking, long may it prevail, and the fact that I have been frugal enough over my lifetime now to be able to afford economy plus when I travel. I also only fly airlines that allow me to preview the available seats on a long haul flight, and assign my own seats. The seat guru website is also a blessing, as it allows you to avoid sitting next to the toilet or in that dreaded row of three or four. I also view an intercontinental flight as an opportunity to get in touch with my inner hermit: no booze, certainly no airline food, but lots of water "imported" on board by me, and to the extent possible, a zen zoning out that allows you to arrive as unpolluted as is possible by the horrible process of flying these days.

After a long flight, we were warmely welcomed to hotel by English speaking staff. We were served Turkish apple tea in the lobby and then shown to our sea view rooms. Rooms were well decorated and well equipped with a modern and spacious bathroom. Special nice touches included a hiotel safe, mini frig and slippers. We spent our early mornings eating a great breakfast on the roof top and our late evening with drinks and snacks on the roof top terrace. Location was very close to all major attractions and yet quiet being on a side street. Hotel offered free airport transport as we stayed at least 3 days. Can't think of a better place to have stayed to explore Istanbul on our first trip to Turkey
The highlight of the hotel is the friendliness and courtesy of the staff. They arranged tickets for us at a show of Turkish dancing and transfers to the airport, plus providing maps and tips on where to go.
We plan to return to Istanbul and would definitely stay at the Valide Sultan , and do not hesitate in giving it a very high recommendation.

http://hotelvalidesultan.com/virtual-tour/

Howie - My point is you do not need to disparage Aaron to make a case for Bonds.  But whatever case you make for Bonds is a lost because his stats are forever tainted.  Your argument about Aaron is more pertinent to Ruth's record but Aaron shouldn't be criticized for making the most of his opportunity.  I don't care where he hit his HRs, Aaron hit a lot of them.

This is a brave, funny, and deeply moving bravura performance. Rain's loving honesty about her father is healing. All of us have complicated relationships with our parents. Rain's journey with her father is inspiring. This play is wildly entertaining and at the same time has a profound resonance. Rain can sing. Rain can act. Rain can dance. And she is a brilliant story teller.

I love this show.

Martin, you are so right. When Reagan closed the mental hospitals in California during the time he was governor, the former patients took up residence in those lovely seaside public parks with bathrooms and sea breezes in Santa Monica, and brought cardboard boxes they found quite suitable for lodging. They developed civic advocacy for their right to squat next. They may have been mental patients but they weren't crazy. They knew a good thing when they saw it.

It's a monarchy I live in over here in UK just now.  Believe me, this is not the form of government the New Republicans are bullying forward.  Dictation is what they're after, the people below responding promptly and with very few questions to a very few vocal people above.   Ugh.

Republicans reap the whirlwind of Reagan's closing the mental hospitals. It is a credit to the American people that these natives of cloud-cuckoo land can survive despite their erratic grip on reality and dysfunctional irrationality. When the going gets tough, these hothouse hybrids sprout a new theory justifying monarchy. They are the exception that proves the rule that education ruins slaves.

A very relatable and funny show. The play centers on a loveable loser who turns the table on his tormentors. Well written and performed by a talented cast we were reciting the lines for hours after the show.

Well if its going to be luxury then they can afford to properly restore the four pinnacles at the very top where terra cotta were replaced by awful simplified aluminium an fibreglass versions in the late 1970s. That at least would be giving something back to the people of New York.

mbs, your comments and others here have helped me understand the dilemmas providers face as to the decision of whether to run a test in cath lab. The shrug this story has gotten from the stock market probably has much to do with that ambiguity.

But I'm curious to know what you think of the allegations that docs performed stent procedures after the tests seemingly showed stents were obviously not indicated. Is there an ambiguity in that situation I'm failing to understand?

Thanks,
Tom Wood
journalist/author, currently writing a history of the for-profit hospital industry (http://on.fb.me/4profhc)

Another problem is the development of governments that live and breathe extortion. Executives will pay a lot of other peoples' money to stay out of jail.

Yes, we need higher taxes on big money, and Congress won't raise them. But something doesn't seem right about raising tens of billions of dollars through bypassing Congress in this way.

Just tax it.

Either way, higher prices passed on to consumers or reduced margins, we'll end up with less GHGs. Unless I'm wrong?

Just finished reading 35 comments...this abnormal rainfall event may be blamed on climate change induced by global warming, but sealevel rise from global warming is not to blame. Far too few people know that a major cause of Metro Manila's worsening floods is that the land there is sinking several inches a year -- more than ten times faster than sealevel rise. This is because the Manila population is exploding, and is pumping out groundwater than much faster than nature can replace it. A fellow Filipino scientist and I published about this in Disasters, an international journal in 2006.

Meanwhile, pious Catholic politicians are saying that God is punishing the Philippines with the floods because its congress is considering a Reproductive Health bill. How very sad...

Richard, sarcasm in and of itself is not an effective rebuttal. This is not just an issue of 'limited government' - the limits and proper role of government can be debated by intelligent and educated people, citing facts and examples drawn from reality. The Tea Party is not conservative, intelligent, or educated. It is ignorant tinfoil-hat craziness. I notice you don't give any specifics as to why the politicians cited in this column are not mistaken (or nuts).

Changing direction:

Superior intelligence scares the masses in a way that beauty and physical strength don't. It's intimidating in the same way that you might feel in a group that suddenly switches to a language you don't speak. 'You know something is happening here, but you don't know what it is, do you, Mr Jones?'

The bigger shock may be that a large percentage of Ivy League grads remain Republicans and will vote for Romney. The Ivy Boomer guys I know watch Fox as their primary source for  "news." Many of their wives seem to prefer Mr. Obama, but my hunch is that even most of them will ultimately vote for Romney in hopes that their taxes will be cut further. Not a single one of these families has sent a son to war since WWII.

regardless of the hysteria coming from new jersey, if we are going to use the term class, then the tea party sentiments are not the product OF the lower classes but the product FOR the lower classes. it is a carefully created and simple message and it has been aided by the media since dick armey first rented the buses to get people to the rallies.
as to skilled workers being liberal..... i know union workers that cried (literally) when reagan died and vote republican regularly. the fact that republicans want to end collective bargaining is lost on them. i have been an employer for 35v years and i don't see a difference in political views in relation to skill level. i see that thoughtful workers are more likely to get to the heart of the matter and make good decisions.

I read Gail's columns as I find them entertaining and informing. But what I am slowly beginning to realize that she and the other Times columnists do not really understand the mentality of the lower middle class like those that vote for Tea Party candidates.

She and the rest of you are educated, have traveled with dined with, and interviewed those who are in the upper echelons of society,. You know the politicians, members of the administration, and have access to them through their agents and supporters.

The people who vote for Tea Party candidates, for right wing politicians, for demagogues that impress them, do not have any contact with even their congressman. The great majority of them do not have college degree, or if they do, it is a two year community college degree in some subject related to their employment.

You have to get down in the trenches with them to understand why they think like they do. I worked many years as a skilled tradesman, and had contact with the assembly line workers, the parts house workers, the delivery guys, the ditch diggers, and others. The skilled workers are more liberal, and many of them are union members. The non skilled workers are the core of the white conservative voter group that will vote for Romney. The believe it is the Liberals that are the cause of their inability to get ahead. They get their opinions from talk radio and Fox News. They do not read about the economy, they let others tell them about it.

No evidence that the rebels are Islamists -- you're misinformed. The rest of is just as confused and murky -- these are the defeatist sentiments of someone who doesn't understand the momentum and expextations planted by the Arab Spring. These events asserted for the 1st time in Arab history the right of the man on the street to say no to the dictator. This is the same logic that is working itself out in Syria -and when it's all over people will ask: what side were we on? Reaction or revolution?

Mr, Kristof, you and others have no idea what the administration is doing about Syria. But one thing is certain, it is a quagmire. We do not even know who to support or how. Remember the Mujahedin in Afghanistan? We gave them stinger missiles and other weapons, and you can see what happened to them.

The rebels in Syria are not one unified group and we have no idea of the outcome. They are Islamist and that probably means they would kill off and evict the Christians who are supporters of the Alewhites. Then you would hear even more complaints about the lack of support. You also seem to forget that Hezbollah is just waiting to see who comes out ahead, and what happens to the military.

Civil order will have to be maintained, but it appears at present no matter who comes out ahead in this conflict there will be reprisals. The Syrian military is still one of the best trained and equipped in the middle east, and the Iranians would like to have them as allies.

We can not simply replace Assad and expect a good result. We can not just arm he rebels and hope they will be our friends in the future. We could not convince Assad to make reforms and go peacefully, now we are stuck with an insurgency that we do not know if w can trust, or what they will do if and when they prevail.

Assad and his military may still maintain power, and that will be really ugly. In any case, there will be revenge killings and religious wars for some time to come.
